 The potential for human neuroimaging to read out the detailed contents of a person's mental state has yet to be fully explored. We investigated whether the perception of edge orientation, a fundamental visual feature, can be decoded from human brain activity measured with functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Using statistical algorithms to classify brain states, we found that ensemble fMRI signals in early visual areas could reliably predict on individual trials which of eight stimulus orientations the subject was seeing. Moreover, when subjects had to attend to one of two overlapping orthogonal gratings, feature-based attention strongly biased ensemble activity toward the attended orientation. These results demonstrate that fMRI activity patterns in early visual areas, including primary visual cortex (V1), contain detailed orientation information that can reliably predict subjective perception. Our approach provides a framework for the readout of fine-tuned representations in the human brain and their subjective contents.

In re: log(base 2)
 
 Ralph V.L. Hartley was the first to use log(base 2) in relation to information in 1928 while working for Western Electric (later Bell Labs). Hartley was working on voice and carrier transmission and formulated the law of information transmission. Shannon continued the use of log(base 2) in his work formulation of information theory, also working at Bell Labs.
 
 Here's how it works. An information source is a stystem that outputs from a fixed set of M symbols. For purposes of discussion assume that each symbol in the set is equaly likely. The probability that symbol i will be produced is p(sub)i = P = 1/M. Any observer is uncertain which symbol is will be produced. The uncertainty is reduced once a given symbol is produced. The amount of information (I) obtained can be measured because the number of possible symbols is known.
 
 I = log(base 2)M
 
 The use of log(base 2) is a measurement of information in bits. Thus, if M= 16, then when any symbol is produced by the system uncertainty is reduced by 4 bits. Compare this to the ASCII code, the 128 character binary representation used in computer communication. If M = 128 then I = 7 bits. In fact, each of the ASCII symbols is represented by 7 bits.
 
 However, log(base 2)M = -log(base 2)1/M = -log(base 2)P
 
 Dembski calls -log(base 2)P a measure of complexity in an effort to define complex information. Dembski's problem is that the above equation has applications to both Classical Information Theory and Algorithmic Information Theory, and Dembski conflates the two.

Similarly, Gitt offers 14 theorems and fails to demonstrate any of them beyond an apeal to his already asserted "principles." Meaning is important to Gitt, yet he fails to define that. Essentially, Gitt's work on information theory is nothing more than assertion and handwaving. In neither Classical nor Algorithmic Informaion Theory is meaning defined - nor is it necessary.
